semantic_identifier: 5958927 - Crimson Meadow Brewing - buy - Discussion with Ryan Dean

hierarchy.meeting_title: 5958927 - Crimson Meadow Brewing - buy - Discussion with Ryan Dean

sections.text: Sneha Reddy: Ryan, good to see you again. Since this is our third call, I wanted to make today really concrete—are we in a place to finalize Customer_Analyzer this week, assuming we can land on the rollout plan and success criteria?

Ryan Dean: Hey Sneha. Yeah, appreciate you keeping it tight. I’ll be upfront: there’s interest, but we’re not aligned internally. Sales wants one thing, Marketing wants another, Product is somewhere else. So I’m not sure we’re ready to finalize.

Sneha Reddy: Totally fair—and honestly that’s exactly the situation Customer_Analyzer is built to de-risk. If you’re open to it, I want to focus on two things only: the fit estimation output—so you can align on who your best customers are with evidence—and the driver breakdown—so each team can see *why* a segment is high or low fit without it becoming opinion-based. Does that map to the sticking point?

Ryan Dean: That’s the sticking point, yes. But we already have reports in the CRM, and Product has their own view from usage. The issue is we don’t trust each other’s numbers, and nobody wants another tool.

Sneha Reddy: Understood. The difference here is we’re not asking you to pick one team’s dataset as “the truth.” Customer_Analyzer ingests the signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding survey answers, usage events, support tickets, even interview notes—and normalizes them into a single fit score from 0 to 100 at both the account and segment level. Then it shows the top drivers contributing to that score. So instead of Sales saying “breweries like X are best” and Marketing saying “no, it’s Y,” you can point to retention, expansion, conversion, and support burden patterns across segments.
Ryan Dean: Okay, but practically—who owns it? If Sales owns it, Marketing won’t use it. If Product owns it, Sales ignores it. That’s been our pattern.

Sneha Reddy: That’s a real risk. What I’ve seen work is: one executive sponsor, but a shared “fit council” in the first month—one person each from Sales, Marketing, Product. The outputs are shared artifacts: an agreed ICP profile plus two or three priority segments. In Customer_Analyzer you can literally compare segments—like SMB vs mid-market—side by side, with driver breakdowns. That makes the conversation about outcomes, not preferences.
Ryan Dean: I get the theory. But we’re slammed. I don’t have appetite for a big implementation.

Sneha Reddy: We keep it lightweight. For an initial pass, you don’t need every signal type. You can start with: CRM fields for firmographics, one or two onboarding questions that reflect problem severity or willingness to pay, and one or two product usage markers that correlate with time-to-value. That’s enough to generate a first fit model and show driver breakdown. Then you decide whether to add support signals or churn risk indicators later.
Ryan Dean: And you’re confident it’ll actually settle debates? Because right now every discussion ends with “it depends” and nothing changes.

Sneha Reddy: It won’t eliminate judgment, but it changes the *starting point*. Instead of “it depends,” you get: “Segment A has a 78 fit score because time-to-value is 3 days, adoption is high, and support burden is low; Segment B is 52 because onboarding completion is low and support tickets spike.” That gives Product a roadmap hypothesis, Sales a targeting plan, and Marketing a positioning angle—without everyone inventing their own story.
Ryan Dean: The part I’m less convinced on is “fit score.” We’ve had scoring models before. They become political.

Sneha Reddy: That’s why the driver breakdown matters as much as the score. If someone disputes the score, you can inspect the drivers: industry, size, tech stack, problem severity proxies, adoption patterns, support burden, churn signals. And you can tune the weights transparently. We’re not asking you to accept a black box.
Ryan Dean: Tuning weights is exactly where politics starts, though.

Sneha Reddy: Fair. So we anchor it to outcomes. The system recommends an ICP profile *based on observed outcomes*—retention, expansion, conversion. You’re not tuning it to make a team “win,” you’re tuning it to match what actually performs well for Crimson Meadow.
Ryan Dean: Let me ask: what’s the immediate deliverable for Product? Because they’re the hardest to get on board. They think this is a GTM thing.

Sneha Reddy: For Product, the use case is product planning: identify high-fit customers with unmet needs to guide roadmap bets. If you can see which segment has high retention but a consistent set of support tickets or feature requests, that’s a roadmap lever. Or if a segment converts well but churns after 60 days, that’s a time-to-value gap to fix. Customer_Analyzer helps connect those dots across sources—usage + tickets + survey responses—so Product isn’t flying blind.
Ryan Dean: That would interest them, but they’ll say they can already do that with analytics and Zendesk.

Sneha Reddy: They can, but it’s usually fragmented and time-consuming. Customer_Analyzer’s value is: one place where those signals roll up into segment comparisons and a recommended ICP profile, plus a driver view that ties it to outcomes. It’s less “another dashboard” and more “a shared decision system” across teams.
Ryan Dean: Okay. Let’s talk buying. You’re pushing to close this week. I don’t see how I get the internal yes that fast.

Sneha Reddy: That’s the crux. What I’m trying to avoid is you spending another month debating ICP with no resolution. If we close this week, we can schedule a kick-off and deliver the first segment fit readout within two to three weeks, assuming access to the core datasets. That gives you something tangible to unify around.
Ryan Dean: The issue is budget approval. And candidly, I don’t have a single exec who wants to sponsor it right now. Everyone likes it, nobody wants to own it.

Sneha Reddy: If sponsorship is the blocker, could you position it as a short pilot that’s explicitly about cross-functional alignment—like “prove we can agree on ICP using evidence”? We can structure it with a clear success metric: “Agree on top two priority segments and one de-prioritized segment based on fit score and drivers,” plus “deliver an ICP profile recommendation backed by retention and expansion signals.”
Ryan Dean: I can try, but the CFO is pushing back on pilots. We’ve done too many “tools for alignment” that didn’t stick.

Sneha Reddy: Then let’s address adoption risk head-on. If you buy, we’ll set a 30-day plan with three specific meetings: data alignment, fit model review, and ICP decision. And we’ll assign owners for each meeting. That reduces “tool shelfware.”

Ryan Dean: Sneha, I hear you. But I’m also dealing with a re-org. Sales leadership might change in the next month. Marketing is rethinking positioning. Product is in the middle of a roadmap reset. It’s not a stable environment to introduce something new.

Sneha Reddy: That’s tough timing. One angle: during a re-org, having a neutral, evidence-based view of “who we win with” can actually create stability. But I don’t want to force it if you don’t have air cover. What would need to be true for you to feel confident signing?
Ryan Dean: I’d need one exec to sponsor it and commit the teams to using it. I don’t have that today. And I don’t think I’ll have it in the next two weeks.

Sneha Reddy: Okay. If the timeline is the issue, we can shift from “close this week” to “decision after internal alignment.” But I want to be careful: if we leave this vague, it’ll drift. Would it help if I provided a one-page internal brief—what signals we ingest, what outputs you get (fit score, driver breakdown, segment comparisons, recommended ICP), and the product planning use case—so you can circulate it?
Ryan Dean: You can send it, yes. But I’m not promising it changes anything. The objections are political, not informational.

Sneha Reddy: Understood. Another option: we do a working session just you and me where we map stakeholders and identify the one question they each need answered. For Sales, it might be “which segment closes fastest and expands?” For Marketing, “which segment responds to which proof points?” For Product, “which segment has high fit but unmet needs?” Then your internal conversation becomes structured.
Ryan Dean: That might help me prepare, but again, I’m not sure it gets us to a signature.
Sneha Reddy: Let’s be explicit then: it sounds like we’re not closing this week because you don’t have sponsorship or stable ownership across Sales/Marketing/Product. Is that accurate?
Ryan Dean: Yeah, that’s accurate. I don’t want to drag you along, but I also don’t want to say “no forever.” It’s more like “not now.”

Sneha Reddy: I appreciate the clarity. Here’s what I propose: I’ll send the one-pager plus a simple rollout plan designed to reduce cross-functional friction—three meetings, defined owners, and the initial minimal data set needed for fit estimation. You take it internally. If you can identify an exec sponsor, we reconvene. If not, we pause.
Ryan Dean: That works. Send it over. And maybe include pricing again—I need it for the CFO conversation, even if it’s not immediate.
Sneha Reddy: Will do. Before we wrap: is there a specific event you expect might create the sponsorship—like after the re-org announcement, or after Q1 planning?
Ryan Dean: Probably after Q1 planning. If we can’t agree on ICP in that process, then tools like yours become more attractive. Right now people think they can muscle through it.
Sneha Reddy: Got it. I’ll send the materials today. Let’s pencil a check-in for shortly after Q1 planning—say four weeks from now—and if things accelerate sooner, you can pull it forward.
Ryan Dean: Sounds good. Thanks, Sneha.
Sneha Reddy: Thanks, Ryan. I’ll follow up with the brief, rollout plan, and pricing, and we’ll regroup after Q1 planning.
